div.head: General
div.p: Abha is the capital of the ˁAsīr province in Saudi Arabia. It consists of several villages that have grown together but kept their distinct names. Abha is located at 2,200m above sea level in the Sarawāt mountains. The dominant clan are the Bani Mġēd of the ˁAsīr tribe.

div.head: Research history
div.p: First information on phonological and morphological patterns in the dialect of Abha in the context of other Saudi dialects was provided by Theodore Prochazka in 1988.

Nakhshabandi‘s 1988 PhD thesis focuses on phonology and morphology. The data is elicited from 10 male speaker’s recorded speech and 4 answers to a questionnaire. Al-Azraqi’s 1998 PhD dissertation grapples with syntax in the Abha dialect. She notes that the different tribes in Abha used to have distinct dialects that are gradually disappearing. She thus suggests that she is dealing with a dialect resulting from merged sub-dialects. Al-Azraqi has also published an article on the verb in 2005 and on dialect contact and change in Abha by the examples of the use of gid (2014), negators (2016) and conjunctions (2017). In 2020, Al-Azraqi published an article on pidginisation in Abha.

Abha is included in Behnstedt’s 2016 dialect atlas. Al-Qahtani’s 2020 dissertation is dedicated to phonology and looks at opaque vowel changes caused by attaching affixes in the light of Stratal Optimality Theory.
